reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay. Where to start? Imagine yourself, for a moment, as a lion. King (or queen) of the Savanna. Within a few minutes you find yourself thirsty. You go down to the wateringhole and have yourself a nice drink. Time to relax? Nope. Now you're hungry. Time to go get food. So you bring down a wildebeast by chasing it around for a few minutes and biting it whenever you can. Eat the meat and now you're full. Time to relax yet? Nope. You're thirsty again. So, to the waterhole again. By the time you find a spot where there isn't a croc eyeing you and get a drink, well how about that, you're starving! Repeat this process two or three more times. Oh, but wouldn't you know it, a meerkat has ran up to you in the tall grass and you can't fricking see it. So you, one of the most deadly predators of the biome, has just been hunted and killed by a small animal that any lion could realistically rip the throat out of with little effort.

This game is horribly unbalanced. Pretty much any animal with an aggressive action can kill any other animal with little effort as long as the aggressor knows what to do. The meters for thirst and hunger run down way too quickly, so it's a constant struggle to keep from going thirsty or hungry that ends up being more frustrating than fun. As a carnivore, you don't feel the thrill of hunting, outwitting, and overpowering your prey, it's just a chore. As a herbivore, it's just a matter of running back and forth from a patch of edible plants and the river over and over again. It gets terribly repetative. The controls are awkward and the button to shift between aggressive and peaceful actions cycles way too quickly with anything more than the very slightest tap likely to land you on the same one you were already on.

If this game interests you, try the free version online first. Trust me, the two aren't all that different and you'll likely understand just how irritating this game is.
voteText: 81 of 96 people (84%) found this review helpful 17 people found this review funny

reviewText: I'm not sure if I understand the point of this game... you sort of spawn into an area as an animal, and you can awkwardly move around an area. Sometimes you randomly turn into another animal. I turned into a bear, and tried to eat a player who was a rabbit. The rabbit obviously knows the game better, because he killed me somehow. Then I think he ate me or mated with me, Im not sure, there's only like 3 sound effects in this game. The animal models don't even act like the animals they're supposed to be. The deer sits like a dog. It's strange. This game feels unfinished, and it's definitely nowhere near a realistic animal sim.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It has the potential to become a very good game, but as of right now, it is practically the same as the Browser verison, although the hackers have (obviously) been eliminated, and there is a large drop in bugs versus the Steam version and Browser verison.
I also noticed something while playing Singeplayer in the Savannah as a Wildebeest. Every Meerkat that saw me was instantly on attack mode and came after me. I find it a bit strange to be killed as a Wildebeest by a Meerkat, not a Lion or Crocodile, both of which never bothered me.
The game needs some major changes and updates, but I believe within the next few months, this game will improve for sure.

-Piff

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Great experience.
I've been playing this from the start including the online version, and there are huge leaps in quality in the last few weeks.
Game play is quirky, and goals are obtuse, but I think that's intentional. Basically If you keep yourself alive you're winning, and what else you do is up to you.
It looks like their answer to hacking is to disconnect the game from the web player version right now. It makes things kinda quiet right now in multiplayer but I guess we'll see how that pans out, and on the upside you can now play directly with your friends via steam, which is a bit more relaxed than the previously manic anything goes" web experience.
I love flying about which feels fluid in a way that many games misss somehow
date: and just running about as an animal is fun.\nThe landscapes are ok
recommended: with beautiful moments mixed with not so beautiful. Generally it looks good.\nIt's not educational
hoursPlayed: it's just mucking about.\nI'd say if you ever wanted to run about like an animal in it's natural environment this game is for you
voteText: but obviously if you want huge story driven game or fps action then it's not.\nWithin it's remit I reccomends it :)\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The idea behind Lif is a unique one. Playing as different animals in their natural habitat as you explore and stay alive can be a fun challenge. This Early Access version is (currently) pretty much the same as Gamevial's free-to-play version in the browser; by paying for the Early Access, you'll get updates that bring Lif closer to its realization as a more realistic animal simulator/survival game.
Lif is open-world, similar to Gamevial's Fly Like a Bird 3, but Lif takes survival to another level. Naturally the animals chase and kill each other constantly because Lif allows you to attack or befriend as you please, but we can expect improvements in gameplay as Lif evolves. There's fun in being able to roam around doing what you want anyway, and we'll be able to do more as the game gets better.
Lif has huge potential, and as with any game, the only way it will improve is by supporting its development.

reviewText:
Liked: This is THE game I have been looking for, I love it!!  I love exploring, learning the maps and finding food, relaxing and enjoying company of others and just having fun.

Disliked: Too many trolls. There is a certain group of trolls on this game and if you aren't one of them they will kill you, follow you from map to map just to kill you and use some sort of trick to just boot you out of the game if they feel too lazy to kill you.

Nobody is allowed to play this game when they're around, which is pretty much nearly all the time. It's not fun to be harrassed like that. When they weren't around, I actually found a nice group and we had baby elephants, baby lions and even baby wildebeeste together.

Then they" came along and somehow one croc slaughtered the entire herd of elephants by himself.

I was a lion once and a meerkat (one of them) was kicking me so I attacked it over and over and it never died.

Now tell me again there's no hackers in Steam: Lif."

reviewText: This game was not fun.  First off, the controls.  WASD is all you have for movement.  No looking up or down or using the mouse to quickly look behind you.  If you want to see whats behind you, you have to hold A or S until you are completly turned around.  You've just climbed to the top  of that hill and now you want to see whats below?  you gotta start walking down before the camera lets you see whats down.  Some people say its fun for 10 minutes.  There is no fun.  I really don't know how some people in here play 400 hours on this thing.   I mean, you walk around, you eat and thats it.  Need to pause the game in single player mode?  Sorry, no pause.  Hit esc and you die.

reviewText:
I've been playing LIF for some years now on the browser version on the Gamevial website.
I found it when I was looking for a online multiplayer animal game and I fell in love since then.
The steam version is MUCH better and has a lot more animals and 2 new maps, which, in my opinion are great. I can say Tundra is my favourite, and the animal models are really well done and there's a lot of variety to choose from.
You can play in both single or multiplayer.
Only con of this game is the amount of hackers, there's a lot and they do ruin it for others who want to play fair.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What I like
< This particular version >:
- A lot better graphics than any previous version on Gamevial.com
- More stable framerate all a better performance altogether
- Good pricing
- Stand-alone game; no more webplayer! <Take that, Chrome>

< In General >:
- Unique, simple gameplay
- Interesting community
- Weirdness; sometimes strange stuff will happen ingame
- Balanced playable characters; Wolf, Rabbit, Deer, Bear, Fox and more!

What I don't like:
- No complaints.

Altogether I'd like to say; Well done, Gamevial. You've created one of the most addicting games ever.
It may have some quirks, but nothing that couldn't be fixed. And now that the game is on steam, it'll
become the game it always wanted to be.

reviewText:
This game is... It. People complain about not getting to pick an animal, clearly they know little about the game before playing.

The idea of using a totem to pick a new animal is interesting to me. You need to work to get the better creatures.

Pros:
-Interesting concept
-The more recent animals have nice models
-Unlike many other games, you gan eat grass
-You can breed
-When on an empty server or single player, there are active npcs
-New and interesting ways to choose a new character
-The animals suit their environments

Cons:
-The older animals have poor animations and models
-It can be difficult to learn the game's mechanics
-Slightly odd controls
-Small array of animals to choose from
-Peculiar mechanics

Overall, more pros than cons, I had fun playing this game!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: There are only a few good animals in this game. Starting as a rabbit, you just eat grass all day. If you attack an animal, it follows you until it dies (singleplayer). Nobody told me you could die of thirst. This is clearly a remake of fly like a bird, but not everybody remembers how to play that game. A little bit of a tutorial or more elaborate control bindings would be nice. Runes on the UI page are cute but unhelpful. Seriously, paws and flowers? Sometimes you just have to get the text out (remember your end users are humans and not dingos). Worth a play though, you might like the game if you can figure it out.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Overall, its OK. Play multiplayer, the NPC in singleplayer are out for blood, so unless you're looking for a fight, try to hang out on a server and chat with anyone online. The graphics are ok and you can learn as you go, but it's a fairly simple game.

I'd say if you're bored and got the extra nine bucks, and like random eat/hangout/fight/wander listlessly games, you'll be ok.

If you want direction, story, or depth, maybe give it a pass. It's pretty much a sandbox.
